instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2530: What is 820-2530? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP1V05_S5: What is PP1V05_S5? PP1V05_S5 is a 1.05v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. On 2008-2009 15” and 17” Macbook boards, this often gets stuck at 0.3v due to a bad C7771 capacitor. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Fan Spin, Nasty Looking LVDS Connector
threads.message:
Just got in an old board to practice on, it gets a green light on the charger, no fan spin.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.56v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> @ <TRANSISTOR>Q7930</TRANSISTOR>: 3.325v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @ L7260: 0v

Should I be checking where the 5V rail is generated or could it be a <SIGNAL>SLP_L</SIGNAL> problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Fan Spin, Nasty Looking LVDS Connector
threads.message:
Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> ?
Do you have <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Fan Spin, Nasty Looking LVDS Connector
threads.message: 5.616 kOhms Resistance to GND on 3v42, there is no <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> showing in the board viewer I checked <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and there is 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Fan Spin, Nasty Looking LVDS Connector
threads.message:
[QUOTE="computercaverva, post: 23363"] there is no <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> showing in the board viewer I checked <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and there is 0v.[/QUOTE]

You do have a schematic for this board, right  ?

If so you'll see <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> produces S5 power for the MCP.

Resistance to GND on the 3.42v rail is low, you could have a malfunctioning MCP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Fan Spin, Nasty Looking LVDS Connector
threads.message: Hmmm, 5.6K on 3V42 is probably a fucked MCP.  If there was corrosion around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> then the MCP is dead for sure.
